DOC.HEAD: Mitterrand Meets East German Leaders; United Germany on Agenda
With PM-Romania, Bjt
Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Mitterrand condemning Romanian leader. Pickup 2nd pvs, `His visit...'
DOC.TEXT: President Francois Mitterrand of France said today that the days of Romanian leader Nicolae Ceausescu are numbered and called for his replacement. ``It is a regime of personal, family power that has no honest reason to remain,'' Mitterrand said at a news conference during his three-day visit to East Germany. ``I think that the days of this regime, in a Europe in full movement, are numbered. But at what price!'' In his first condemnation of the bloody suppression of protests in Romania, Mitterrand ruled out foreign intervention to topple Ceausescu. He said ``the response has to come from Romania.'' Mitterrand also met with East German political leaders today to express the concerns of the West about the possibility of German unification. His visit came as West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl told West German lawmakers that the Germanys plan to strengthen all economic and political ties. But Kohl also tried to ease the concerns of European nations worried about a united Germany, saying the growing closeness of the two countries can only help the continent. Meanwhile, the West German government said East Germany would open Berlin's Brandenburg Gate on Friday. The gate is a historic portion of the Berlin Wall viewed by many as a symbol of German unity. Kohl, East German Premier Hans Modrow, West Berlin Walter Momper, and East Berlin Mayor Erhard Krack will participate in the historic ceremonies, said government spokesman Hans Klein. The official East German news agency ADN said Mitterrand met with Modrow and that the ``joint responsibility for balance in Europe'' was the main topic. Mitterrand and Modrow also discussed the possibility of expanding ties, while the East German premier expressed interest in a trade and cooperation agreement with the European Economic Community, ADN said. It added that Mitterrand had reacted ``positively'' to the idea of closer East German ties to the EEC. But before leaving Paris on Wednesday, Mitterrand said: ``For the whole of Europe, it would not be good _ indeed it would be very dangerous _ to reopen the issue of the existing borders.'' In an interview with East German television, he also said the ``two paths open for the Germans are the democratic path and the peaceful path.'' The possibility of reunification was raised after the pro-democracy movement recently forced the Communist Party in East Germany to oust its hard-line leaders, lift travel restrictions and open the Berlin Wall. Mitterrand arrived Wednesday, a few hours after Kohl Germany ended an emotionally charged visit to East Germany that brought out thousands advocating reunification. During Mitterrand's visit, French and East German officials are to sign several agreements, including a five-year project for closer economic and technical cooperation. At a state dinner Wednesday hosted by East Germany's interim president Manfred Gerlach, a non-Communist, Mitterrand paid tribute to the East German pro-democracy movement and said the Germans should determine their own future. But he stressed that ``no country may impose its political system on another.'' He said closer German ties would result in the context of a strengthened European Community and a general overcoming of the continent's division. Mitterrand is representing the 12-nation EC, whose rotating presidency France holds until Dec. 31. He is also the first head of state from the three western World War II Allies to visit East Berlin. The United States, Soviet Union, France and Britain have ultimate authority over Berlin, a result of the postwar occupation of Hitler's defeated Third Reich. While relations between Kohl and Mitterrand are close, the French leader's statements before his trip highlighted traditional French wariness of a strong Germany at the heart of Europe.
